court: Civil Court of the City of New York, Kings County

claims.name: Non-payment of rent
claims.claim_description: Petitioner's claim that respondents owe $45,900 in unpaid rent from February 2017 through April 2019 at $1,700/month

claims.name: High rent vacancy decontrol exemption
claims.claim_description: Petitioner's claim that apartment was lawfully deregulated in 2008 and is exempt from rent stabilization due to high rent vacancy

claims.name: Rent overcharge counterclaim
claims.claim_description: Respondents' counterclaim that apartment remains rent stabilized and petitioner charged illegal rent

evidence.name: DHCR registration records
evidence.description: Three conflicting DHCR registrations showing different apartment designations (1R, 1Right, 1Stright) with inconsistent rent history and exemption claims
evidence.source_quote: the registrations were rife with errors, as petitioner's witness conceded

evidence.name: Lease agreements
evidence.description: Leases showing rent history from 2004-2009 including Mora ($1,118), Perez ($1,508.06), Gordon ($1,800), Miller ($2,160)

evidence.name: Petitioner's discovery response
evidence.description: Petitioner's admission that no documents exist for individual apartment improvements despite claiming $200 IAI in 2005
evidence.source_quote: No documents responsive to this demand still exist notwithstanding there was an IAI for $200.00 in 2005

evidence.name: Witness testimony of Deodat Lowton
evidence.description: Testimony admitting conflicting DHCR registrations, gut renovation claims without documentation, and errors in registration filings
evidence.source_quote: he testified that he did not have any of these documents

required_evidence.name: IAI renovation documentation
required_evidence.description: Invoices, receipts, contracts proving Individual Apartment Improvement costs
required_evidence.evidence_source_reference: Charles Birdoff & Co. v. DHCR; 756 Liberty Realty LLC v Garcia

required_evidence.name: Rent stabilization rider
required_evidence.description: Written notice to first tenant after deregulation explaining how and why apartment is no longer rent stabilized
required_evidence.evidence_source_reference: NYC Admin Code ยง 26-504.2; RSC ยง 2522.5(c)(3)

outcomes.name: Petition dismissed with prejudice
outcomes.description: Court dismisses the petition with prejudice, determines apartment is subject to rent regulation, and directs petitioner to offer proper rent regulated renewal lease

outcomes.name: Apartment remains rent stabilized
outcomes.description: Court determines apartment remains subject to rent regulation based on petitioner's failure to prove lawful deregulation

damages.name: $45,900 unpaid rent claim
damages.description: Amount petitioner sought for unpaid rent from February 2017 through April 2019 - denied due to failed proof of deregulation

damages.name: Rent overcharge damages
damages.description: Potential damages respondents may be entitled to from rent overcharge counterclaim (amount to be determined based on legal regulated rent)

damages.name: Rent regulated renewal lease
damages.description: Court directs petitioner to offer respondent a proper rent regulated renewal lease based on the ascertainable legal rent

presented_evidence.description: Testimony admitting errors and no documents

critical_gaps: No documentation proving IAI cost (invoices, receipts, contracts)
Rent stabilization rider not provided to first deregulated tenant
